titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Paul Bullock Papers LSC.1303
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Manuscripts Division staff.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2020 December 3.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-31 16:11:33 -0700.

did.abstract: Paul Bullock (1924-1986) was a research economist at the UCLA Institute of Industrial Relations (1953-85). The collection consists of audio tapes on reels and cassettes, transcripts, manuscript drafts, and clippings related to Bullock's research for three published books. The books are, Watts: The aftermath / by the people of Watts (1970), Youth in the labor market: employment patterns and career aspirations in Watts and East Los Angeles (1972), and Jerry Voorhis, the idealist as politician (1978).
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed audiovisual materials. For information about the access status of the material that you are looking for, refer to the Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed digital materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Paul Bullock papers (Collection 1303). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Bullock was born in Pasadena, California, on November 6, 1924; received his BA and MA, Occidental College, 1948 and 1949; performed graduate work, UCLA, 1948-50; economics instructor, El Camino College (1949-50) and Occidental College (1950-51); research economist, UCLA Institute of Industrial Relations, 1953-85; published writings include: Watts: The aftermath / by the people of Watts (1969), Youth in the labor market: employment patterns and career aspirations in Watts and East Los Angeles (1972), Creative careers: minorities in the arts (1977), and Jerry Voorhis, the idealist as politician (1978); founder and president, Jazz Heritage Foundation; died February 14, 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of audio tapes on reels and cassettes, transcripts, manuscript drafts, and clippings related to Bullock's research for three published books. The books are, Watts: The aftermath / by the people of Watts (1970), Youth in the labor market: employment patterns and career aspirations in Watts and East Los Angeles (1972), and Jerry Voorhis, the idealist as politician (1978).

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Audio tapes, transcripts, and drafts for Watts: the aftermath (Boxes 1-2).
Audio tapes and transcripts for Jerry Voorhis (Boxes 3-4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Undated or post-dated tapes found in envelope marked "Watts Tape#2".

These appear to have been used in preparing Aspiration vs. Opportunity; "Careers" in the Inner City (Ann Arbor: Institute of labor and Industrial Relations, University of Michigan--Wayne State University, 1973), and the trade edition of Youth in the Labor market: Employment Patterns and Career Aspirations in Watts and East Los Angeles [Los Angeles: Manpower Research Center, Institute of Industrial Relations, University of California, 1972].

did.unittitle: Watts; the Aftermath. New York: Grove Press
Transcripts and Drafts of Unidentified Sections of the Book
Paul Bullock, Richard Townsend, William Armstead.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p:
Some or all of this material may also pertain to Aspiration vs. Opportunity: "Careers" in the Inner City. Ann Arbor: Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations, University of Michigan--Wayne State University, 1973.
i) Number Two tape [Education] 1 item, 10 pieces.
ii) Tape #3. 1 item, 20 pieces.
iii) Paul Williams. 1 item, 69 pieces.
iv) On police, concluding remarks. 1 item, 2 pieces.

list.item: ii)"My name is Sydney Sedgie Collins..." 1 item, 17 pieces.

did.unittitle: "One thing whites must realize..." and "The majority of middle class people..."
Drafts of Identified Sections of Watts; the Aftermath. New York: Grove Press

list.item: ii) #1 Tape: "the Middle Class" (pp. 182-183 of the book). 2 items, 6 pieces.

did.unittitle: Interviews of Jerry Voorhis by Paul Bullock
Newspaper Transcripts Concerning Jerry Voorhis's 1946 Congressional Election Campaign Against Richard Nixon

list.item: ii) Photocopy of A.L.S. to R.O.D. 1946.

did.unittitle: Questions on the 1946 Voorhis-Nixon Congressional campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Notes on the Japnese internment from Richard R. Lingeman, Don't You Know There's A War On? New York: Putnam, 1970.]
